text: A landing at the top of a crooked, wooden staircase. Ther a threadbare, braided rug on the floor. There is a long, corridor decorated with faded paintings of sailboats and battleships. The wallpapers are sun-bleached and peeling the corners except for a few newly-hung strips which are clean and bright. A small easel sits stored in the corner Outside, a hard rain falls, drumming the roof and rattlin the gutters. A ten-year-old boy in pajamas comes up the steps carefull eating a bowl of cereal as he walks. He is Lionel. Lionel slides open the door to a low cabinet under the window. H takes out a portable record player, puts a disc on the turntable, and sets the needle into the spinning groove. A child's voice says over the speaker:

In order to show you how a big symphony orchestra is put together, Benjamin Britten has written a big piece of music, which is made up of smaller pieces that show you all the separate parts of the orchestra. As Lionel listens, three other children wander out of the bedrooms and down to the landing. The first is an eight-year-old boy in a bathrobe. He is Murray. The second is a nine-year-old boy in white boxer shorts and a white undershirt. He is Rudy. The third is a twelve-year-old girl in a cardigan sweater with knee-high socks and brightly polished, patent-leather shoes. She is Suzy. She carries a one-month-old striped kitten. The boys drop down to the floor next to their brother. Th lie on their stomachs with their chins propped up on thei fists, listening. Suzy sits in the windowsill. She opens a book called Shel and the Secret Universe. There is an illustration on the cover of a young gymnast with a glowing amulet around her neck. Suzy starts to read -- then pauses. She lowers her book. raises a pair of junior binoculars to her eyes. She looks into the rain. 2.

A rickety, three-story, stone-and-shingle house on a hill with turrets and a widow's walk. A weather vane swings creaking on the roof. Tree tops sway in a cluster below. sea is almost invisible in the misting rain, and the main is a shadow across the sound. Suzy sits in the high windo watching.

The family stuck indoors all day out of the rain. In bedrooms, bathrooms, and corridors, we see the boys. T shoot marbles. They throw jacks. They play cards. They ea grilled cheese sandwiches together in the kitchen. In half-open doorways, we see the parents. Mr. Bishop is tall, fifty-year-old man in Madras trousers and horn-rimm glasses. He reads the newspaper and drinks coffee. Mrs. Bishop is a tan, forty-five-year-old woman in a Lilly Pulitzer-type wrap-around skirt. She washes her hair, topless, in the kitchen sink. In windows, we see Suzy with her binoculars. She watches branches shaking in the woods. She watches a man in a sli fishing from a row-boat. She watches a white colt in a fi She eats a bowl of tomato soup alone in the pantry. In the distance, a seaplane flies by below the clouds.

The edge of a cliff above a white beach. A rocky peninsul curls into the background. Brisk wind rustles the tall gr A fifty-year-old man, bald on top with long hair on the sides, stands next to a surveyor's levelling instrument o tripod. He wears rubber boots and a parka. He is the narrator. He speaks to the camera:

This is the island of New Penzance. Sixteen miles long. Forested with old- growth pine and maple. Criss-crossed by shallow tidal creeks. An important seabird habitat. There are no paved roads but instead many miles of intersecting foot paths and dirt trails and a ferry that runs twice daily from Stone Cove. The year is 1965. We are on the far edge of Black Beacon Sound, famous for the ferocious and well-documented storm which will strike from the east on the fifth of September -- in three day's time. 3.

A clearing in the woods with ten small, khaki tents pitch in a row. A banner on a flag-pole ripples in the wind. It reads Camp Ivanhoe. A bugler in a khaki uniform with a ye neckerchief plays a staccato tattoo. He has a gauze patch over one eye. He is Lazy-Eye. A thirty-five-year-old man in the same uniform emerges through the flaps of a larger tent. He is Scout Master Wa He puts on a wide-brimmed felt hat. A badge on the crown reads Khaki Scouts, Troop 55. He lights a cigarette. A th scout with curly hair and sunglasses joins him at his sid He is Gadge.
Morning, Gadge.

Morning, sir. Gadge flips open a small, spiral-bound note-book. Scout Master Ward goes over to a latrine made from thick sticks rope. A tall, stooped scout digs a trench next to it with army-shovel. He is Deluca.
Deluca. Latrine inspection. Deluca stops digging. He pulls on a rope and water runs d a chute. It bursts through a valve, spins a little door, a small, red flag flips up. Scout Master Ward nods.
Good. Gadge makes a note. Scout Master Ward strides away. He st in front of a scout with long hair over his eyes sitting stump twisting something in his fingers. He is Roosevelt.
Roosevelt. How's that lanyard coming?
I don't know. I think I skipped a stitch.

A small, woven, multi-colored cord with a rabbit's foot attached to the end of it. It has been braided exceedingl badly and is brutally twisted and misshapen. 4. Scout Master Ward studies the lanyard briefly. He looks perplexed. He pats Roosevelt on the back gently and does secret handshake with him. Gadge makes a note. Scout Mast Ward strides away. An off-road motorcycle races by in the background behind tents. It jumps a mound of dirt, kicks sideways in the ai and revs away riding a wheelie. Scout Master Ward frowns. Scout Master Ward stops in front of a pile of boards and stacked six feet high. A thick-set scout with black hair a crooked tooth approaches with more logs in his arms. He Skotak.
Skotak. What's all this lumber for?

We're building a tree house. Skotak points up. Scout Master Ward squints. There is a s platform under construction about sixty feet above them. scouts are sawing something in half on it. Scout Master W looks astonished.
That's not a safe altitude. Scout Master Ward circles around the trunk while looking at the tree house. He stammers:
Why's it up so high? If somebody falls -- it's a guaranteed death.
Well, where would you've built it?

Lower! Gadge makes a note. Skotak looks sheepish. Scout Master W strides away. He stops in front of a very small scout wit tiny eyes poking at an anthill with a stick. He appears t contemplating pouring lighter fluid on it. He is Nickleby
Nickleby. Spot check. Nickleby stands up. He looks extremely disheveled. 5.

Your socks are down. Your shirt-tails are untucked. Your trousers are not properly pressed. You are reported for uniform violation! Gadge makes a note. Nickleby slouches. Scout Master Ward strides away. He stops in front of a work-bench covered w newspaper where one scout sifts green powder through a fu into cardboard tubes and another makes wax stoppers with metal press. They are Panagle and Izod. A sign on the sid the table reads No Smoking. Scout Master Ward hands his cigarette to Gadge, who holds it away at arm's length.
How many rockets you up to, Panagle?
Sixteen and a half.
That enough for the Jubilee? Gadge shakes his head. Scout Master Ward turns to Izod.
Izod, go fetch another pint of gun-powder from the armory shed. Izod dashes around the corner. Scout Master Ward strides away. He shouts:

Redford! Halt! The motorcycle skids to a stop in front of Scout Master W engulfing him in a thick cloud of dust. He coughs and wav his arms in the air. As the smoke clears, we see that the rider is a bronze, all-American-looking boy with blond ha He is Redford. His motorcycle has flames painted on the g tank. He tries to cover for himself:
Safety-test, sir.
Come again?
The vehicle appears to be in good working order. I'm just checking if -- 6.

Reckless cycling. Second warning. Next time, I take away the keys. Gadge makes a note. Redford scowls. Scout Master Ward str away. He walks past a scout in a white apron cooking baco over a charcoal grill. He is Chef.

Morning, Chef. Chef rings a bell hanging on a post. Scout Master Ward arrives at a long picnic table. He sits down and opens a magazine called Indian Corn. There is a picture on the co of a scout troop crossing a bridge in Indonesia.

The first page. A caption across the top reads Scout Mast in-Chief. There is a drawing of a seventy-year-old man on horseback. He has silver hair and a moustache. A signatur below reads Commander Pierce. There is a quotation in lar text: "An eagle was never hatched from a goose's egg." As Scout Master Ward reads, all the scouts begin to join one-by-one. They range in age from twelve to fifteen. The unscrew the tops of tin mess-kits and assemble folding utensils. The chef brings a tray of scrambled eggs to the table. The scouts serve themselves noisily. Scout Master Ward starts to take a sip of coffee from a m cup -- then stops. He looks up from his magazine.
Who's missing? Scout Master Ward silently reels off a list of names, scanning the troop. He turns and shouts across the camp:
Shakusky! Breakfast! Silence. Scout Master Ward calls to Lazy-Eye:

Lazy-Eye. Lazy-Eye plays another tattoo. Silence. Scout Master Ward closes his magazine. He flicks his cigarette into a red bucket labelled Fire. He picks up a strip of bacon and chews on it as he rises to his feet an walks down the row of smaller tents. The last one is seal 7. at the front. Scout Master Ward stands with his hands on hips and says:
Shakusky? You in there? Scout Master Ward tugs on the tent's flaps. He frowns. He says to Gadge:
It's zipped from the inside. The other scouts begin to gather with their tin breakfast plates in their hands, watching curiously while they eat. Scout Master Ward's voice softens:

Sam? Scout Master Ward looks concerned. He produces a wooden- handled scout pocket-knife. He unfolds a few blades and gadgets and decides quickly on a thin tool with a hook on end. He crouches down and slips the hook through a small at the base of the flap, twists left and right, then pull briskly, unzipping the tent.

The lining of the tent is printed with images of trees an pine cones, and a plaid rug covers the floor. There is a locker, a gas lamp, a chair with a folded blanket over it and an empty cot. Scout Master Ward steps inside slowly, over, examining the space. He lifts the lid of the foot locker. He looks under the corner of the mattress. He pic up a piece of folded yellow notebook paper sticking out f under a pillow. He opens it and stares at it. He turns suddenly to the chair against the wall of the tent and sl it aside. There is neat but slightly jagged hole the size of a basketball cut through the fabric in the back corner. Sco Master Ward looks to his staring troop.
Jiminy Cricket. He flew the coop.

A one-room bungalow with a sign on the door that reads Is Police. There is a wood-panelled station wagon parked alongside it with roller-lights on the roof and a sheriff office insignia on the door. (This is the only car on the island.) A dock stretches from the cottage into a small 8. harbor. There is a launch moored at the end of it which b in the rough tide. A silver Airstream trailer is parked under a tree nearby. A six-foot tall, forty-five-year-old man sits on a stool fishing from the side of the dock. He wears a short-sleev police uniform with a black necktie and a baseball cap. H glasses have clear, plastic frames and a strap. He is Cap Sharp. Two grouchy, leathery, very old men in plaid flannel and hunting caps fish alongside Captain Sharp. A speaker on a post emits an electric buzz. Captain Sharp turns. He stan up briskly and says to one of the old men:
Watch my line, Edgar.
A small office with a desk, a file cabinet, and a two-way radio. Captain Sharp comes inside, sits down, grabs a microphone, and presses a red button on the side of it wi his thumb.
Hello? This is Captain Sharp. Over. Scout Master Ward's voice comes over a crackly speaker:
Captain Sharp, this is Randall Ward over at Camp Ivanhoe. Over. Captain Sharp pours himself a cup of coffee from a pot on hot-plate as he answers distractedly:
Morning, Randy. What can I do for you? Over.
I'm not sure, exactly. I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. Over. Silence. Captain Sharp frowns slightly.
What does that mean? Over.
One of my boys seems to have stolen a dug- out and some fishing tackle, ten pounds
SCOUT MASTER WARD (V.O.) (cont'd) of sundries, two bedrolls, plus an air rifle -- and disappeared. Over. Captain Sharp slowly stirs sugar into his coffee as he contemplates this. He says finally:
Any idea why? Over.
No. He left me a letter of resignation. Over.
A sheet of wide-ruled yellow paper which reads in a boy's

Dear Scout Master Ward, I am very sad to inform you I can no longer be involved with the Khaki Scouts of North America. The rest of the troop will probably be glad to hear this. It is not your fault. Best wishes, Sam Shakusky. Captain Sharp scratches his head. He checks his watch. Pa
I guess we better notify his folks. Over.
OK. Over and out.
A clapboard cottage surrounded by a white, picket fence. sign on the door reads U.S. Mail. Captain's Sharp station wagon is parked in the background.

A young woman with her hair in a bun sits at an operator' switchboard eating a sandwich wrapped in wax-paper. She i Becky. She wears bulky head-phones with a microphone attached. Captain Sharp paces behind her. Scout Master Wa flips through a stack of letters and post cards. A bell rings on the switchboard. Becky plugs cords into sockets.
Hello, Diane. 10.
Becky, I have your person-to-person from Chesterfield.
Hold the line, please. Becky signals to Captain Sharp and Scout Master Ward. The sit down quickly and put on their own sets of operator he phones.
Go ahead, Chesterfield.

Split-screen. On one side of the frame, we see Captain Sh Scout Master Ward, and Becky. On the other side, we see a seventy-five-year-old man with a grizzled face sitting at kitchen table drinking coffee and smoking a cigarette whi white-haired woman ices a cake in the background. They ar Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. Mr. Billingsley says into his
Hello?
Hello, sir. This is Captain Sharp.

Yes, sir. I received your message. Thank you very much. In fact, we've come to a decision, as a family, because this is only the most recent incident involving Sam's troubles, and it's just not fair to the others, so, unfortunately -- we can't invite him back, at this time. Captain Sharp, Scout Master Ward, and Becky all look puzz Captain Sharp says evenly:
There's no cause for alarm, sir. We'll find him. We're just notifying you as a matter of protocol and so on.
I understand that. I'm notifying you of the situation on my end.
I'm confused by that statement. You can't invite him back? 11.

I'm afraid not. He's a good boy, he's got a good heart, but it's just not fair to the others, you see? He's emotionally disturbed. Long pause. No one moves except Mrs. Billingsley icing he cake. Captain Sharp says finally:
Am I speaking to Sam's father? Mr. Billingsley frowns. He says, surprised:

No, sir. Sam's parents passed away a number of years ago. We're Mr. and Mrs. Billingsley. We're foster parents. Sam's been with us since last June. Mrs. Billingsley has stopped icing her cake. She watches Billingsley. Scout Master Ward interjects:
Excuse me, sir. This is Scout Master Ward speaking. Are you implying Sam's an orphan?
Well, it's a known fact. Of course, he is.
Why the hell doesn't it say that in the register? Excuse my language. Scout Master Ward holds up a manila file-card. Mr. Billingsley shrugs.
I don't know. What register?

The manila file-card. It is labelled Khaki Scout Register Sam Shakusky is typed across the top line. There is an address, health information, and a small, faded snap-shot stapled to the corner of it of a twelve-year-old boy stan in a sunny tobacco field. He wears his scout uniform with Davy Crockett-style coon-skin cap.

We sent him a letter. It should reach you presently. 12. Scout Master Ward looks quickly through his stack of lett He stops and pulls out an air-mail envelope. He stares at Captain Sharp says forcefully but highly agitated:
Mr. Billingsley, I've got an escaped Khaki Scout. We're notifying you as a matter of protocol. You say you can't invite him back? You say he's an orphan? Well, I don't understand how that works.
What am I supposed to do with him?

That's up to Social Services. They'll be in touch with you. They'll look after Sam. Good luck to you. Mr. Billingsley hangs up the telephone. Becky pulls the c out of their sockets. Captain Sharp looks to Scout Master Ward. Silence. Becky opens a tin of home-made chocolate chip cookies. Captain Sharp declines one. Scout Master Ward tries one. looks very impressed.
Scout Master Ward stands on a bench addressing his assemb troop. The scouts are equipped for hiking with back-packs walking-sticks.

You have your orders. Use the orienteering and path-finding skills you've been practicing all summer. Let's find our man and bring him safely back to camp. Remember: this isn't just a search party, it's a chance to do some first- class scouting. Any questions? Lazy-Eye raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him
Lazy-Eye.
What's your real job, sir?
I'm a math teacher. 13.
What grade?
Eighth. Why? Lazy-Eye shrugs. Scout Master Ward frowns.
You know, we're, actually, kind of, in the middle of something, if you didn't notice. This is a crisis. Anybody else? Redford raises his hand. Scout Master Ward points to him.
Redford.
What if he resists?
Who?
Shakusky. Are we allowed to use force on him?

No, you're not. This is a non-violent rescue effort. Your instructions are to find him, not to hurt him. Under any circumstances. Do I make myself understood? The scouts murmur their understanding. Scout Master Ward nods.
Good. Pause. Scout Master Ward wheels back to Lazy-Eye:
I'm going to change my answer, in fact. This is my real job. Scout Master, Troop 55. That's us. I'm proud of that. The scouts look impressed but slightly lost. Scout Master Ward says finally: 14.
Be leery out there. OK, let's get started. Where's Snoopy?
Right here. Skotak holds up a leash attached to a wire-haired terrier Scout Master Ward takes a sock with a fleur-de-lis on it of a paper sack.
Give him the scent. Scout Master Ward hands the sock to Skotak.
Redford, Deluca, Nickleby, Lazy-Eye, and Gadge at the bac the group talking under their breath while Skotak waves t sock under the dog's nose:
I heard he ran away because his family died.
I heard he never had any family in the first place.
That's probably why he's crazy.
I'll tell you one thing: if we find him, I'm not going to be the one who forgot to bring a weapon.
Me, neither.

The troop moves in a wide line searching through a thicke skinny trees. Redford carries a net and a giant tomahawk sling. Deluca has a large hunting knife tucked under his belt. Panagle holds a walking stick with a cluster of nai sticking out on the end of it. Nickleby, Izod, and Lazy-E all wear bows and quivers of arrows strapped to their bac The wire-haired terrier strains at the end of a leash, sniffing down a foot-path. 15. Scout Master Ward speeds up the river in a small boat wit out-board motor. He gives orders over a walkie-talkie. Ga steers. Captain Sharp stands on the doorsteps of various big hous showing the snap-shot of the missing scout to: an elderly woman, a house-keeper, a group of children, a priest. The all shake their heads. Captain Sharp drives his station wagon down a beach, thro a field, and over a bridge.

Captain Sharp stands at the front door talking with Mr. a Mrs. Bishop. Mr. Bishop holds a glass of red wine in one and an open bottle in the other. Mrs. Bishop looks slight uneasy. They both study the snap-shot.
Camp Ivanhoe? That's all the way across the other side of the island. You really think a twelve-year-old boy could row this far in a canoe?
Most likely not.
(with a shrug) It's possible, Counsellor.
I disagree, Counsellor. It'd take him three days, at least.
I don't think so. Two days, maximum.
Well, I'm not going to argue about it.
Be that as it may, will you let me know if you see anything unusual?

A binocular shot of Captain Sharp from overhead as he wal away down the front steps. He passes Lionel, Murray, and on their way up the path. They wear wet bathing suits and towels around their shoulders. Captain Sharp pats Rudy on top of his head. He dries his hand on the leg of his 16. trousers. He gets into his station wagon, backs out of th driveway, circles through the woods, and drives around to small dirt road a hundred yards behind the house. He stop the car. He gets out, sits on the hood, and lights a cigarette. Suzy watches from the widow's walk with her binoculars. S lowers them. She looks curious. She raises them back to h eyes and sees: Mrs. Bishop from overhead as she comes out the back door the house carrying a basket of damp laundry. She pauses a clothesline, looks left and right, then walks quickly int the trees. She crosses a foot-bridge and arrives at the d road. Captain Sharp stands up. They talk briefly but intensely. Mrs. Bishop leans against the car and stares i space. Captain Sharp touches her hair. Mrs. Bishop makes gesture with her fingers. Captain Sharp hands her his cigarette. Mrs. Bishop takes a puff, hands it back, and strides away again through the woods. Captain Sharp gets his station wagon and drives off.
A portable night stand. There is a reel-to-reel tape reco recording on it. A framed photograph next to it shows the Scout-Master-in-Chief posing with a troop in front of the Matterhorn.

head_text.subj: INT. SCOUT MASTER WARD'S TENT. NIGHT

text: The front flaps are tied-open, and a mosquito net is draw hanging lantern flickers on a hook. A bugle plays a varia of taps in the distance. Scout Master Ward sits on a cot dressed in pajamas. He smokes a cigarette and drinks a gl of brandy while he speaks tensely into a microphone:

Scout Master's log. September second. First day of search party for Sam Shakusky. Morale is extremely low, in part, I suppose, because Sam is, unfortunately, the least popular scout in the troop, by a significant margin. I'm worried, and I'm confused. Please, let us find him tomorrow. Please, don't let him fall off a cliff or drown in the goddamn lake or something. A terrible day at Camp Ivanhoe. Let's hope tomorrow's better. In fact, I'm going to say a prayer. Scout Master Ward presses stop. He kneels down on the flo closes his eyes, presses his palms together, and whispers 17.
Scout Master Ward zips up his tent and turns off the ligh Crickets chirp. Bats circle. The wire-haired terrier digs carefully through a pile of trash.

The next morning. A fast current runs along a shallow rav deep in the forest. The boy from the snap-shot rows a min canoe painted with Native American tribal symbols and severely over-loaded with boxes, bags, and blankets. He w a pellet gun slung on a strap over his shoulder and his c skin cap. He smokes a pipe. A sash across his chest is decorated with numerous small, embroidered patches. There a woman's enamelled brooch pinned to his shirt. It is a jeweled, black scorpion. He whistles to himself quietly a steers under a fallen tree-trunk and winds through gentle rapids. He is Sam.
An eddy under a willow tree. The end of the canoe is tied a branch, and the cargo is stacked on the shore. Sam cove the boat with a camouflage net and dresses the top with p needles.
Sam hikes through a pass wearing an extremely large back- with stakes, metal poles, and two bed-rolls strapped to t bottom. He wears a compass on a string around his neck.

A binocular shot of Sam emerging from the woods into a wi meadow. The grass comes up to his chest and flows in wave He pauses to check his compass. He spins slowly one direc and then back the other while he stares at the dial. He l up again. He walks onward. He stops.

Suzy lowers her binoculars. She stands at the end of a pa cut through the high grass. She has a leather folder in o hand, the portable record player in the other, plus a sma suitcase and her kitten in a basket at her side. Sam take his coon-skin hat slowly off his head. He strides across meadow. Suzy watches him approach. She swallows. Her lips part. Sam comes onto the path. He stops ten feet away fro Suzy. Sam and Suzy stare at each other. Silence. (NOTE: Suzy is slightly taller than Sam.) 18.
A poster box with St. Jack's Church across the top. A pur ink mimeographed page is stapled to a bulletin board insi under the heading Summer Pageant, 1964. It reads:
Performed by the Choristers of St. Jack Wood and New Penzance
Dusk. A brick church at the top of a bluff overlooking th bay. It is overgrown with ivy and wisteria. There is a cemetery with a low wrought-iron fence. An organ plays inside.
One Year Earlier

A play is in progress. The set includes a long ark with a sail built on a platform behind the altar. Two teenagers crouched in the wings ripple a narrow, blue sheet across foot of the stage. (This is meant to be water.) The rest the room is dim, with tall candles flickering along the center aisle. The beams are draped with garlands. A large congregation fills every pew plus folding chairs against walls. More people sit and stand on the steps to the choi loft at the back and in nooks and corners. The members of brass ensemble seated beside the organist wait for their cue, following their sheet music with instruments poised. Khaki Scouts and scout masters occupy the rear section of church. A very young troop in a slightly different versio the uniform fills a row near the exit. Sam sits on the ai He looks bored. A baritone built like a linebacker in robes and a fake be sings ominously on the stage. Cymbals crash. Sam stands u and discreetly wanders toward the side door with his hand his pockets. A slight, forty-year-old man in the same uni watches him from the end of the pew, frowning.

Sam quietly entering the lobby. The sound of the music deadens as he gently shuts the door behind him. He turns around and puts on a yellow scout cap with Junior Khaki stitched on the bill. The room is jammed with children dressed as animals, waiting nervously in a long line that 19. winds all around the space. They whisper and shuffle. A l woman stares through a small window into the church with hand on a doorknob. She is Mrs. Lynn. She snaps her finge suddenly without looking to the children. They fall silen Pause. Mrs. Lynn swings open the center doors. Music fills the r again. The first twenty of the children begin to sing. Th march out of the lobby, two by two. The woman closes the doors behind them, and the next group takes their place t wait. Sam walks slowly among otters, monkeys, squirrels, and skunks, examining their costumes, periodically touching horns, tusks, and teeth. No one pays attention to him. He drinks a sip from a water fountain. He picks up a mint fr bowl and sucks on it. He slips out through a swinging doo
Sam moves down a dark corridor. Voices murmur. He pokes h head around a corner. A rack of choir robes and cassocks blocks his path. He slides two of them apart and looks

Five eleven-year-old girls in black leotards sitting on a bench in front of a mirror framed with light bulbs. They quietly and fix their make-up. They all wear wings on the arms and beaks on their heads. Suzy sits among them in bl feathers. Sam stares at her. He steps into the light silently. Suzy sees him in the reflection. The other girl turn around quickly, covering themselves. Sam removes his cap and takes another step forward. His e dart briefly among the other girls. He says to Suzy:
What kind of bird are you? Suzy hesitates. She looks to the girl next to her, who sa in a bossy voice:
I'm a sparrow, she's a dove, and -- Sam does not look away from Suzy as he interrupts, pointi
No, I said, "What kind of bird are you?" The other girls all look to Suzy. Pause.
I'm a raven. 20. Suzy lifts her beak slightly higher on her forehead. The other girls look annoyed but transfixed. The bossy girl frowns.
Boy's aren't allowed in here. Sam does not look away from Suzy as he answers quietly:
I'll be leaving soon. Sam points down at Suzy's lap. One of her hands is wrappe a bandage.
What happened to your hand?
I got hit in the mirror.
Really. How'd that happen?
I lost my temper at myself. Sam is deeply intrigued by this. The other girls look puzzled. Suzy presses her hair back off her face. She wat Sam nervously.
What's your name?
Sam. What's yours?
I'm Suzy. Sam nods with his eyes still glued to Suzy's. Suzy bites fingernails. The bossy girl rolls her eyes.
It's not polite to stare. Sam holds up his hand for the bossy girl to stop talking. Mrs. Lynn steps into the doorway.
Birds! Ready? 21. Mrs. Lynn does a double-take. She snaps at Sam:

Who are you? Where'd you come from? Go back to your seat. Sam hesitates. He spits the mint into a trash can, ducks through the clothing rack, and is gone. A skinny girl dre as an owl watches Suzy while the other girls hurry to the feet. She says quietly:
He likes you.

Troops flood out from one side of the church while childr in animal costumes flood out from the other. They criss-c among grave-markers and head-stones. Sam stops abruptly, to face with the skinny owl. She whispers something, poin behind her, and thrusts a folded scrap of paper into Sam' hand.
A vehicle crowded with scouts. Sam sits alone in the back row. He stares into space, entranced.
Suzy on-stage at the top of a pedestal with her arms in t air, spreading her wings. She is surrounded by the entire cast of singing animals. The music soars.
Sam as he looks down at the piece of paper in his hand.
A sheet of pink stationary with an address in a girl's re felt-tip cursive and the words: Write to me.
The present. Sam and Suzy face each other in the wide mea Sam says carefully:
Were you followed? 22.
I doubt it.
Good. Sam frowns and squints. He points.
Did you bring a cat? Suzy nods. Sam smiles. Suzy smiles. Sam takes a folded ma out of his pocket. He signals for Suzy to come closer.
Can you read a map?
Uh-huh.
I do cartography. Sam points to one of the patches on his sash. It has a protractor embroidered on it. He unfolds the map.
I feel we should go halfway today and halfway tomorrow, since you're a less experienced hiker, and you're wearing Sunday-school shoes.
(pointing on the map) Here's where we are right now. I'd like to pitch camp here by sixteen-hundred (which means four o'clock). How does that sound?
Fine.
You want some beef jerky?
Sam tears a strip of dried meat in two and gives half to Suzy. She tries to chew on it. Sam nods: 23.
Let's go.
Sam and Suzy walk together down a hill, across a field, a through a wooded path eating beef jerky. They both smile continuously.
Are you thirsty?
No.

Well, if your throat gets parched, stick a pebble in your mouth and suck on it. You can quench your thirst with the spit, supposedly. Sam shows Suzy some bits of green and yellow sticking out from under his coonskin cap.
Sometimes I stick leaves under my hat. It cools your head down.
That's a good idea. It might help also if you didn't wear fur.
True, but this adds camouflage. Sam stands in a clearing and pulls a handful of dry grass holds it in his fist.
Here's a trick. Throw grass in the air, and you can see which direction the wind's blowing. Sam throws up the grass. It swirls and drifts vaguely. Su squints.
Which way?

Unknown. I guess it doesn't really matter, as long as we cover our tracks. 24. Sam and Suzy stop to investigate and discuss: a patch of mushrooms, moss on a stump, ferns, poison ivy, and a low with purple fruit. Sam looks skeptical.
These might be poisonous.
No, they're huckleberries, in fact. Try one. Suzy brushes off some dirt and eats a berry. Sam puts one into his mouth and nods.
Not bad. Anyway, they're good for survival. Sam and Suzy look through Suzy's binoculars at a deer drinking from a stream. Suzy whispers:
He knows someone's watching him.
I agree. Why do you say that?
I don't know. I just think he can feel us. Sam and Suzy walk across a fallen tree over a stream. A s swims on the surface below them. Sam assists Suzy onto th far bank.
You smell like perfume.
It's my mother's. Sam picks up two pebbles. He and Suzy both put them in th mouths. They click against their teeth.

I brought water, too. Sam and Suzy watch a small, green worm wriggling in the a swaying from a silk thread. They stare, wide-eyed. Suzy c her hand a few inches below it and moves it around in a circle. Sam shrugs. 25.
Should we catch him?
What for?
Trout bait. We need worms.
No. Pause. The worm curls and uncurls itself gently. Sam nods
You're right. We'll let him live. Maybe I've got a licorice whip.

The banks of a large pond. All of Sam's and Suzy's bags, boxes, and suitcases are arranged around a small tent decorated with more tribal symbols. The kitten is asleep. and Suzy stand at the water's edge as he removes the camouflage net from the canoe and says gravely:
How strong of a swimmer are you?

Fish on hook!

It's not funny.

To me, it is. Sam slaps his knee and shakes his head. Pause. Suzy dumps fish into the campfire and throws her metal plate like a frisbee into a tree trunk. It bounces off with a ding. Sh stands up and says coolly:

He tentatively approach the bush. He looks behind it. He takes two steps closer. stands above Suzy. He unties his neckerchief, crouches do and holds it out.

Which one's the best?

Dusk. Sam lies on his back on one of the bedrolls smoking pipe while Suzy sits Indian-style next to him. She reads aloud from a book called The Francine Odyssies. There is illustration on the cover of an enormous panther with a bloody sword walking behind a small girl in a nightgown.

His eyes downcast, his kingdom in ruins, Mynar pressed his heavy paw through the rippling surface of the cool shallows and down to its stone floor. "My people once were lead by a great and noble beast -- and I no longer see his face in this reflection." Suzy looks to Sam. He is asleep. Meanwhile, on the Plains of Tabitha, Francine rested. There would be another time for war.

The dining room. There is a long, wide, empty table with sixteen chairs around it. Tucked in the corner, Lionel, Murray, and Rudy sit at a folding card table. They have plates on place-mats and forks and knives. There is one e seat. Mrs. Bishop's voice booms, amplified, from the next

Good evening. Sorry to startle you. I was

Dear Suzy, I have been trying very hard to make friends, but I feel people do not like my personality. In fact, I can understand why they might -- A classroom of sixth graders watches in a panic as Suzy throttles one of her classmates. The classmate flails and grimaces as she is strangled.

In particular, I recall his fascination with the idea of retracing the original path of the old Chickchaw harvest migration. Long pause. Everyone looks utterly perplexed. The propell of the seaplane starts up, and they all shield their eyes from the blast of wind and dust. The narrator hesitates. yells over the noise:
What I'm getting at is this: I think I know where they're going. The narrator removes the rubber bands from his journal.
A carefully hand-drafted nautical chart. A cove is marked with a red arrow and the caption Mile 3.25 Tidal Inlet.
The portable record player. Suzy's fingers place the need onto a spinning disc.

A small cove enclosed by a low, rocky cliff. It forms an almost complete circle and is overgrown with vines, flowe and branches. A thin channel leads out to the ocean. The on the shore is white, and the water is perfectly clear a crowded with shells at the bottom. Birds echo and fly fro tree to tree. Sam's and Suzy's luggage is piled on the beach. The kitte wanders, exploring. The lid of the portable record player open. The voice of Leonard Bernstein says over the speake 50.

Onto the bird-house, where every kind of bird imaginable is whirling and wheeling around. This is a real acrobatic act for our gifted young flute player, Paula Robeson. As they listen, Sam and Suzy take off their shoes and soc and run in opposite directions around the edge of the cov They each climb up a rock over the water. They look at ea other across the lagoon. They both laugh. Suzy shouts,
This is weird.

I know! Sam takes off his coon-skin cap and throws it aside. Suzy removes her cardigan and drops it on the ground. Sam stri off his uniform down to his white briefs. Suzy take off everything except her underwear and a training bra. They throw their clothes into the water. Sam yells:
On three! Suzy immediately counts very quickly. They both scream as they leap into the water. They swim toward each other, laughing and shouting.

A clothesline hung with Sam's and Suzy's wet clothes sway like flags and snapping in the wind. The tent has been pitched on a low, sandy plateau close to the water. Two l of shells mark a path to the entrance. A long stick is ja into the ground with a flickering safety-candle stuck int the Y at the top. The kitten is asleep. Sam sits on a folding stool in front of a portable easel. dips his brush into a tin cup and paints. Suzy poses stretched out and propped up on one arm. She adjusts hers slightly.
I like it here, but I don't like the name.
Me, neither. 51.
Mile 3.25 Tidal Inlet. It's got no ring to it.
Let's change it. What should it be?
Let me think for a minute. Sam continues to paint while Suzy thinks.
A binocular shot of a deep blue, star-filled sky. Suzy lies on her back on a flat rock in the middle of the cove looking up into the night. Sam wades out to her and climbs up beside her.
I made you some jewelry. Sam holds up two dead, shimmering, opalescent beetles wit fish-hooks threaded into their shells. Suzy looks enchant
Are your ears pierced?

Inside the tent, lit by a lantern. Sam clenches his teeth he forces one of the fish-hooks through Suzy's earlobe. S screams murderously. Sam releases her. The beetle dangles neatly. A line of blood runs down the side of Suzy's neck Sam holds up a little mirror. Suzy nods.
It's pretty. Do the other one. Sam switches to Suzy's other earlobe. She resumes her screaming.

Sam and Suzy standing on the beach listening to the Frenc singer's record. They face each other, bobbing their head and tilting awkwardly to the music. Suzy eventually begin dance. Sam does something vaguely like the Twist. They pr against each other and kiss. Suzy says quietly:
It feels hard. 52.
Do you mind?
I like it.
Tilt your head sideways. Sam and Suzy kiss again. Sam pushes his hands through Suz hair and draws it back behind her ears. Suzy whispers:
You can touch my chest. Sam slides his hand up under the training bra and presses onto Suzy's breast.
They're going to grow more. Sam nods. He looks to be in a trance.
Sam and Suzy sitting on a tree branch over the water eati raisins from Sam's hand. Suzy has flowers in her hair. Sh looks down into the water with her binoculars.
Why do you always use binoculars? Suzy thinks for minute. She says finally:
It helps me see things closer. Even if they're not very far away. I pretend it's my magic power.
That sounds like poetry. Poems don't always have to rhyme, you know. They're just supposed to be creative. Suzy gives Sam the binoculars. He points them at her and stares.
What do you want to be? When you grow up. 53.
I don't know. I want to go on adventures, I think. Not get stuck in one place. How about you?

Go on adventures, too. Not get stuck, too. I guess that sounds almost like I'm just repeating what you just said, but I couldn't think of anything as good as it. On the other hand, maybe we'll get blown up by an atom bomb. You can't predict the exact future.
That's true.
It's possible I may wet the bed, by the way. Later, I mean.
I wish I didn't have to mention it, but just in case. I don't want to make you be offended.
Of course, I won't.
Some people frown on these problems. Suzy nods. She holds Sam's hand. She points to the scorpi brooch pinned to Sam's shirt.
What's that one for? Sam looks at the brooch. He shakes his head.
It's not an accomplishment. I inherited it from my mother. It's actually not meant for a male to wear -- but I don't give a damn. Suzy nods thoughtfully. Pause. 54.
Are your foster parents still mad at you? For getting in trouble so much.
I don't think so. We're getting to know each other better. I feel like I'm in a family now. Not like yours, but similar to one.
I always wished I was an orphan. Most of my favorite characters are. I think your lives are more special. Sam frowns. Tears suddenly well-up in his eyes. He shakes head.
I love you, but you don't know what you're talking about. Long pause. Suzy says genuinely:
I love you, too.

A campfire burns in front of the tent. Sam lies on his ba on one of the bedrolls smoking his pipe while Suzy sits Indian-style next to him. She reads aloud from a book cal The Light of Seven Matchsticks. There is an illustration the cover of a child's hand extinguishing a little flame. ribbon of smoke curls between its fingers.

The flashlight's beam drew a moon through the black across the attic and settled on a gap in the base-board. A mouse-hole, no bigger than a pocket-watch. Eric crouched on his flat feet and placed his hand in front of the tiny opening. "It's windy," he said. "Like someone in there's blowing on my fingers." Christy rolled her eyes and sighed a sigh. He's right again, she thought. Little brothers drive people crazy. Suzy looks to Sam to see if he is still awake. Sam nods a signals for Suzy to continue. Suzy turns the page and rea
Part Two.

The next morning. Sam and Suzy are asleep with their arms wrapped around each other inside the tent. They wear only their underwear. The sound of an airplane approaches. Sam eyes open. The noise buzzes by loudly overhead. Suzy sits Sam scrambles to his feet, unzips the flaps of the tent, looks out. Suzy crouches beside him, holding onto his leg

Captain Sharp standing on the beach fifteen feet away. Sc Master Ward waits behind him with Gadge, Skotak, and Lazy Eye. Mr. and Mrs. Bishop stride up out of the water. Mr. Bishop looks incensed. They are wet to the waist. The pol launch is moored in the lagoon. Two larger boats with St. Jack Wood Fire Brigade printed on their hulls float furth away. Men in red caps stand on their decks. Suzy pulls Sam back inside. She zips up the tent again. S kisses Sam. Mr. Bishop hollers:

Suzy! Get out here! Mr. Bishop grabs hold of the entire tent by the top and r it up out of the ground, uprooting the stakes which go flying. This reveals: Sam and Suzy, half-naked, entwined, kissing. Mr. and Mrs. Bishop both freeze. Sam and Suzy look up to them. Mr. Bishop growls and roars at them ferociously lik monster. Sam and Suzy look horrified. Mr. Bishop's face suddenly drains of all emotion. Pause. Mrs. Bishop comman Sam and Suzy:

Put your clothes on. Both of you. Sam and Suzy remain perfectly still. Mrs. Bishop grabs Su by the arm and jerks her to her feet. Sam and Suzy hang o each other. Mrs. Bishop slaps Suzy with a whack. Sam lets and Suzy is gone. Scout Master Ward comes over to Sam sadly and hands him h uniform. Sam takes it. Scout Master Ward turns to the oth scouts, claps his hands twice, and says: 56.
Strike this camp. Sam starts putting on his socks. Captain Sharp watches hi

Captain Sharp drives his boat along the coast with a grim look on his face. Suzy rides in the back with Mr. and Mrs Bishop. Sam rides in the front with the other scouts. An interrogation is in progress:
How long were you planning to stay there?
I don't know.
You said ten days or less.
That was a lie.
Didn't you ever think about what would happen next?
Not to my recollection.
You're a traitor to our family.
Good. I want to be. Scout Master Ward sits next to Captain Sharp. He shows hi the air-mail envelope.
What do I do about this? Captain Sharp shrugs. He says, resigned:
Give him his mail. Scout Master Ward turns to Sam. He holds out the envelope Sam takes it. He opens it. He reads. Suzy watches him fro across the boat. She calls out anxiously:
What does it say? 57.
They can't invite me back.
Why not?
I gave them too much aggravation. Suzy stands up. She says as she starts across the boat:

Let me read it. Sam holds out the note. Mr. Bishop pulls Suzy back down t her seat. He stands up, himself, and walks over to Sam. H takes him by the wrist and leads him to a small cabin. He opens the door and presses him forward. Sam stumbles down steps and looks back. Mr. Bishop shuts the door. Captain Sharp glares at him. Suzy says icily:
That's child abuse. Mr. Bishop returns to the back of the boat and sits down again. He gives Suzy a direct order:
Be advised: the two of you will never see each other again. Those were your last words. Do you understand?
I'd be careful if I were you. One of these days somebody's going to be pushed too far, and who knows what they're capable of.
Is that a threat?
It's a warning. Suzy looks from Captain Sharp to Mrs. Bishop and back to Bishop. Mr. Bishop falls silent. 58.
I wish I knew what makes you tick.
I beg your pardon?
Please, terminate this conversation.
She's saying that to me? Lionel shakes his head bitterly. Suzy stares out to sea. Scout Master Ward walks over to the cabin, opens the door and goes inside.

A small room with two bunks, two portholes, and a pile of ropes. Sam sits hunched over with his hands in his lap. H stares at the envelope. Scout Master Ward sits down acros from him. He motions to the envelope and says quietly, pausing between each sentence:

I'm sorry about this. I didn't know your situation. It's not on the register. How'd you lose your parents? I shouldn't ask that. Never mind. I wish we had time for an inspection back there. On the beach. I would've given you a "commendable". That was one of the best- pitched camp-sites I've ever seen. Honestly. Sam does not respond. Scout Master Ward asks in a wounded
You don't want to be a Khaki Scout anymore? Sam shakes his head.
Becky sits at the switchboard with her head-phones on. Captain Sharp and Scout Master Ward sit behind her wearin their own sets of head-phones. There is a click on the ot end of the line. 59.
Hello, Becky.
Judy, I have your person-to-person from New Penzance.
Go ahead, New Penzance.

Split-screen. On one side of the frame, we see Captain Sh Scout Master Ward, and Becky. On the other side, we see a fifty-year-old woman in a blue and white uniform pants-su with a Salvation Army officer-style hat and a red ribbon in a bow around her neck. She is Social Services. She sit a desk in a cinder block office. Guards and orderlies cri cross in a bullet-proof window to a long, grey corridor behind her.
Hello? This is Captain Sharp. Social Services flips open a file-folder and picks up a b point pen. (She takes notes throughout the conversation.) says into her telephone:
Hello, Captain Sharp. This is Social Services. I'm calling in reference to Sam Shakusky, Ward of the State. I understand he's in your custody.
That's correct.
What's his condition? Has he suffered any injury or trauma of any kind?
He's OK.
Very good. How do I get to you?
The fastest way is by seaplane. Jed can bring you in with the mail.
I'll come tomorrow morning, if that's acceptable to you. Is someone able to
SOCIAL SERVICES (cont'd) provide reasonable care and nourishment for the boy until that time?
Uh-huh.
Is that a yes?
Uh-huh.
Very good. I'll contact you again before the end of the day. Social Services starts to hang up the telephone. Captain Sharp says abruptly:
Wait a second.
Yes?
Social Services?
Captain Sharp.
What's going to happen to him? Pause. Social Services puts down her pen. She clasps her hands together in front of her. She says finally:

Well, normally, we'd try to place him in another foster home, but that option is no longer available to us, in my opinion, with his case history -- which means he'll go to Juvenile Refuge. Captain Sharp exchanges a look with Scout Master Ward. Sc Master Ward interjects:
What's that? An orphanage? Social Services frowns. She asks calmly: 61.
Who's speaking?
This is Scout Master Ward. Social Services refers to a document in her file-folder. nods.

Right. An orphanage -- but the first step is the admissions panel requires a psychological evaluation to determine whether or not the boy's a candidate for institutional treatment or electroshock therapy. Beyond that --
Excuse me. Shock therapy? Why would that be necessary? He's not violent. Social Services picks up the document. She points to it.
The report describes an assault with scissors.
That was the girl! Who did that.
Well, maybe she needs help, too -- but that's not our job. OK?

Social Service hangs up the telephone. Becky pulls the co out of their sockets. Scout Master Ward looks to Captain Sharp. Silence. Becky opens a tin of home-made lemon bars. Captain Sharp declines one. Scout Master Ward tries one. He looks completely enchanted.

The living room. There is a wicker rocking chair, a vase filled with wilted wildflowers, and a portrait of some 62. Pilgrims hanging over a stone fireplace. Lionel, Murray, Rudy sit together on the floor playing Parchesi. Mr. Bishop lurches into the doorway, shirtless. He carrie open bottle of red wine with a glass in one hand and a lo handled woodsman's axe in the other.
I'll be out back. Lionel, Murray, and Lionel look up from their game. Mr. Bishop hesitates. He seems slightly disoriented.
I'm going to find a tree to chop down. Mr. Bishop exits. Pause. Lionel rolls a pair of dice.

Old linoleum floor. Dark curtainless window. One bare lig bulb. Suzy sits erect in the bathtub staring blankly into space. Mrs. Bishop washes her with a soapy sponge. Suzy's clothes and leather folder are in the corner with the kit scratching at them.
I do know what you're feeling, Suzy-bean. I've had moments myself where I say: what am I doing here? Who made this decision? How could I allow myself to do something so stupid --
-- and why is it still happening? We women are more emotional. You have to
Suzy turns to Mrs. Bishop and interrupts:
I hate you.
Don't say "hate".
Why not? I mean it.
You think you mean it. In this moment. You're trying to hurt me. 63.
Exactly.
I know what you do with that sad, dumb police man. You go to bed with him. Mrs. Bishop looks stunned. She says quietly:

He's not dumb, but I guess he is kind of sad. Anyway, we shouldn't discuss that. It's not appropriate for me to even acknowledge what I already just said. Mrs. Bishop sees something sticking out of the leather folder. She pulls it out and stares at it. It is the "Cop with the Very Troubled Child" pamphlet. She looks to Suzy Suzy looks away. Mrs. Bishop sighs deeply and says, on th verge of tears:
Poor Suzy. Why is everything so hard for you? Suzy starts to cry. She covers her face. Her voice breaks

We're in love. We just want to be together. What's wrong with that? Mrs. Bishop puts her arms around Suzy. Suzy shakes, silen sobbing. Mrs. Bishop pulls some twigs and stems out of Su hair. She studies the beetle earrings. She says wearily:
Oh, my God. How are we going to get these fish-hooks out?
Captain Sharp cooks sausages on a skillet in a kitchenett He has a bottle of beer in his hand. Sam sits waiting at fold-out table with a glass of milk in front of him. He s without looking up:

I admit we knew we'd get in trouble. That part's true. We knew people would be worried, and we still ran away, anyway -- but something also happened which we didn't do on purpose. When we first met each other. Something happened to us. 64. Captain Sharp stirs the sausages in the pan. He nods. He

I agree with you. That's eloquent. I can't argue against anything you're saying -- but I don't have to, because you're twelve years old. Captain Sharp brings the skillet to the table and serves three links onto one plate and three onto another. He sit down.

Look, let's face it, you're probably a much more intelligent person than I am. In fact, I guarantee it -- but even smart kids sometimes stick their fingers in electrical sockets, if you see what I mean. It takes time to figure things out. It's been proven by history: all mankind makes mistakes. It's our job to try to protect you from the dangerous ones. If we can. Captain Sharp pours an inch of beer into a glass and slid it over to Sam.
You want a slug? Sam nods. He and Captain Sharp both drink sips. Captain S asks gently and sincerely:
What's the rush? You've got your whole life in front of yourself. Ahead of you, I mean.
Maybe so. Anyway, you're a bachelor.
What does that have to do with it? So are you.
That's true. Did you love someone ever? 65.
Yes, I did.
What happened?
She didn't love me back.
Ah. Sam considers this. Captain Sharp looks depressed. They s eating their sausages. Captain Sharp says quietly:
I'm sorry for your loss. Anyway, that's what people say.
Thanks.
What happened?
A drunk truck driver smashed into them.
Good grief. Silence. Captain Sharp refills both their beer glasses.

head_text.subj: INT. SCOUT MASTER WARD'S TENT. NIGHT

text: Scout Master Ward sits on his cot in his pajamas again wi cigarette in his mouth. His tape recorder is recording. H says into the microphone:

Scout Master's Log. September fourth. Scout Master Ward hesitates. He thinks for a minute. He t a deep breath. He closes his eyes. He opens them again. H looks desperate. He looks up at the ceiling. He shakes hi head. He presses stop. He kneels on the floor with his pa together and smokes. There is a slight commotion outside. Scout Master Ward
Stow it, out there! I want to hear some Z's!

The fort sixty feet above the camp. It is still under construction. The entire troop (with the exceptions of Redford and Sam) has gathered for a clandestine meeting. all wear pajamas. Skotak stands on a balcony with his bac the group and his hands on a wooden railing.
I heard he's going to reform school.
I heard they're going to take out a piece of his brain and send him to an insane asylum.
I like his girl.
She's too scruffy for me.
Supposedly, they got to third base.
That's not true. He just felt her up.
Over-shirt or under-shirt? Skotak slams his fist on the railing. Everyone looks startled. Skotak turns around to face the group. He says

Damn us. The railing collapses behind Skotak, ripping part of a wa and a row of shingles off the structure as it falls away. There is a moment of silence before it hits the ground wi splintering thud. Skotak hesitates. He moves a half-step from the edge. He continues:
This troop has been very shabby to Field Mate Sam Shakusky. In fact, we've been a bunch of mean jerks. Why's he so unpopular? I admit, supposedly, he's
emotionally disturbed -- but he's also a disadvantaged orphan. How would you feel? Skotak moves among the group, looking from face to face,
Nickleby? Deluca? Lazy-Eye? (from the heart) Gadge? Skotak circles around the edge of the tree house. He says
He's a fellow Khaki Scout, and he needs our help. Are we man enough to give that? So part of his brain doesn't get removed out of him. Skotak stands still. He says mysteriously:

They were prepared to die for each other out there. Silence. The other scouts begin to murmur to each other, shaking their heads, shrugging, whispering, and gesturing Finally, Deluca looks up to Skotak.
What do you need?
For starters? Three yards of chicken wire, some ripped-up newspapers, and a bucket of wheatpaste.

A thick tree has been chopped almost completely through i trunk. For some reason, it remains standing. Mr. Bishop s on the ground leaning against it. He breathes heavily. Th axe rests across his lap. A twig snaps. Mr. Bishop looks up, listening. Pause. He drinks a sip of wine. In the background, on the other side of the lawn, five sm silhouettes run silently in a row away from the house int the trees on the left. A moment later, one taller silhoue rides a bicycle silently away from the house into the tre on the right. 68.
Captain Sharp sits on the hood of his station wagon. Mrs. Bishop leans against it with her bicycle in front of her. They smoke cigarettes. Captain Sharp says sadly:
In other words, it's over.
I guess so. For the moment.
Until further notice.
That's right.
I understand.
I've got to do better. For everybody.
Except me.
Except you.

Well, I hope you can. I think you will. You're doing the right thing. Pause. Captain Sharp suddenly slides his hand inside Mrs. Bishop's shirt onto her breast and simultaneously kisses -- then just as suddenly gets into his car and starts the engine. Mrs. Bishop hesitates. She reaches inside the win and puts her hand on the top of Captain Sharp's head. She says, worried:
Who know what's going to happen, Duffy? I'll probably see you tomorrow.
No, you won't. Silence. The motor idles. Captain Sharp says distantly: 69.
I admire them, you know? There's a purity to it. I only feel bad because they both seem like such unhappy, lonely, miserable people -- but maybe that's romantic.
I don't see it that way. Captain Sharp puts the car into gear and drives off. Mrs. Bishop finishes her cigarette. She gets on her bicycle an rides away.

A burning match drops down into the fireplace near the fo of a bunk where Sam lies sleeping. He has the sheet pulle to his chin, but his toes stick out. He opens one eye. Du descends and settles. Something scrapes and scratches. Th flame burns out. Sam slides slowly off the mattress and creeps across the floor. He crouches in front of the fireplace. He flicks o scout flashlight and sees: The end of a hanging rope. Sam leans quickly into the fireplace and looks straight u shining his flashlight. Skotak is looking down at him fro the top of the chimney. He puts his finger to his lips. S
Get out of my chimney.
Listen to me. We're here for friendship. We're going to get you off this island.
No, thanks.
Yes, thanks. This is an emergency rescue.

It's worthless to me. There's no point. Not without Suzy. Skotak gestures for Sam to wait. He disappears from view. moment later, Suzy's face appears at the top of the chimn smiling toothily. Sam looks ecstatic. 70.
How'd you get here?
They snuck me down the laundry chute and left a paper-mache dummy in my bed.
Diversion tactics. Good thinking.
The next room. Captain Sharp sleeps in boxer shorts on th floor of the kitchenette in the dark. He snores quietly.
Five mini-canoes race across a wide, choppy strait close the open sea. Skotak, Deluca, Nickleby, Gadge, Lazy-Eye, Panagle, Roosevelt, Chef, and Izod paddle aggressively. W hear in voice-over:
Where we going?
Fort Lebanon. My cousin Ben runs the Supply and Resources outpost for the Jubilee. He's a Falcon Scout, Legionnaire. Cousin Ben'll know what to do.
Can we trust him?

Normally, I'd say no. Sam and Suzy ride in the back of the canoe that Skotak ro Sam has his arms around Suzy's waist. The kitten is on he shoulder. Sam sees the portable record player among Suzy' things.
Did you leave another note for Lionel?
Not this time. He can't keep his trap shut. Besides, I'll probably never see him again. 71.
That's true.

A pebble beach below high dunes. Large waves sweep into t shore. Spray blows through the air. There is a black lighthouse on a rocky point in the distance. The narrator stands at the water's edge holding a meteorologist's measuring stick. He braces himself against the gusting wi He speaks to the camera:

This is the island of St. Jack Wood, extending far north from Land's End along the deep-water channel that leads to Broken Rock. A low flood-plain separates the beach from the town-ship above. A small but prosperous community. The narrator takes out a pocket barometer. He reads it. H

The barometer reads twenty-seven inches and dropping. Strong winds, as you can see, already at twenty-two knots. (checks his watch) The time is now four thirty-five A.M. The narrator walks quickly out of the shot. The five cano land on the beach with the tide. Sam, Suzy, Skotak, and t rest of the troop quickly jump out and drag the boats up shore.

The room is black. Mr. and Mrs. Bishop lie in separate si beds side-by-side. They both stare at the ceiling. The windows rattle, the walls creak, and trees sway outside. Long pause. Mrs. Bishop whispers:
Did you file the motion for continuance? Peabody vs. Henderson.
It was sustained.
Good. 72.
Did the judge consider your application for leniency? Rogers vs. Yentob.
He granted it.
Great. Silence. Mrs. Bishop's voice breaks as she says quietly:
I'm sorry, Walt.
It's not your fault. Which injuries are you apologizing for? Specifically.
Specifically? Whichever ones still hurt.

Half of those were self-inflicted. Mrs. Bishop shakes her head and smiles with tears on her face. A powerful blast of wind shakes the room. A night-l blinks. Mr. Bishop has a lump in his throat as he says:
I hope the roof flies off, and I get sucked up into space. You'll be better off without me.
Stop feeling sorry for yourself.
Why? Mr. and Mrs. Bishop look across at each other in the dark Mrs. Bishop says desperately:
We're all they've got, Walt. Mr. Bishop takes a deep breath. He says finally, with a
It's not enough.

Flashlight and lantern flames flicker over the jagged wal Skotak is curled in a blanket on a high rock. Gadge is tu into a sleeping bag under a ledge. The troop nestle on ro and ledges in bedrolls and sleeping bags all around the d cavern. Sam lies on his back on one of the bedrolls smoking his p while Suzy sits Indian-style next to him. She reads aloud from a book called Annabelle's Midnight. There is an illustration on the cover of a blonde girl climbing out a window onto a trellis with fireflies circling around her.

"-- but I'm not going," said Barnaby Jack. "I'm running away tonight for good, and this time I won't get caught." Annabelle whispered: "I'm coming with you." Her yellow hair, now brown at the roots, caught up in the wind and danced. Barnaby Jack took Annabelle's hand and pressed something into it the size of a jellybean. "Hide this in your socks, and be ready at midnight." Suzy looks to Sam to see if he is still awake. Sam looks the rest of the troop to see if they are still awake. The all nod and signal for Suzy to continue. Suzy turns the p and reads on:
He leapt out the window and landed in the fresh-fallen snow.

The next morning. Camp Ivanhoe. Scout Master Ward emerges from his tent. He puts on his hat. The wind whips it off head. He chases it, catches it, and puts it back on with chin-strap tight. He frowns. He shouts:

No bugle? No reveille? Lazy-eye, Gadge, Deluca, Izod? Where's my troop? Let's go! You're late! Scout Master Ward tries to light a cigarette, but the mat blows out. He walks past the latrine, the workbench, the of smaller tents, and the charcoal grill. He throws his h into the air. 74.

Chef? Breakfast? Scout Master Ward shakes his head. He arrives at the picn table and rings his bell. He sits down. He opens a new is of Indian Corn. There is a picture on the cover of a scou troop rappelling in Tasmania. He struggles to keep the rippling pages from turning by themselves.

The first page. There is another drawing of the Scout Mas in-Chief. This time he is behind the wheel of a ship. His signature below, once again, reads Commander Pierce. Ther a quotation in large text: "Anyone can hold the helm when sea is calm." Pause. Scout Master Ward lowers his magazine. He looks around, confused. Something dawns on him.

A small entourage of teenage scouts studies maps, charts, documents at folding tables. One of them sits at a telegr machine. He wears headphones and taps Morse code on a pad as he listens to a transmission. He looks puzzled. He swi his chair to a steno-machine and begins typing rapidly.

A triple-sized tent with a canopy in front and a large to pole looming over it. It stands on five-foot stilts. Ther a school bus parked next to it with letters painted acros its side which read Regional Jubilee. A forty-five-year-old scout master with several medals on chest is sharpening a straight razor. He is Secretary McIntire. He adjusts a hot towel on the face of a man in barber's chair. The young telegraph operator hurries out of the tent carr a strip of paper. He hands it to Secretary McIntire. Secretary McIntire stares at it. He says to the man under

You're not going to believe this one, sir. That Scout Master on New Penzance? Has now lost his entire troop. The seated man whips the towel off his face and rises to feet. He is Commander Pierce himself. He has silver hair, moustache, and a much greater number of medals. He says i disbelief as he snatches the slip of paper: 75.
Well, I'll be damned. Who is this bimbo?
I couldn't say. Commander Pierce shakes his head. He continues to study t document as he sits back down. Secretary McIntire begins lather his cheeks with a brush.

A vast archway of wood, straw, and rope construction. For Lebanon is spelled out across the top with bound sticks. large flag waving madly on a pole reads Khaki Scouts of N America. A bugler on a platform plays the familiar stacca tattoo. It echoes for miles. Sam and Suzy wait inside the gates crouched behind a row trash cans with the rest of the troop except Skotak. They shiver. Sam has on his back-pack. Suzy carries her suitca Gadge holds a tennis ball can. A scout master in an Indian chief's headdress stops as he walks by. He looks curiously at Sam and especially Suzy. says to Nickleby:
